article.body: NEW YORK â I remember the Daily News headline: âFORD TO CITY: DROP DEAD.â It seemed preposterous. Gerald Ford had announced at the National Press Club the day before that he would veto any federal financial bailout for New York City. Also, he never actually used those words. Still, a president threatening the capital of the western world? Pshaw! I had known I would live in New York City since my earliest family excursions there as a tyke. As the family car would ascend the rise over Queens that revealed the skyline, I was filled with awe and wonder. I had to be there to know it. “ âNew York City was alive in a way the suburbs couldnât touch: teeming with the creative expression and diversity that seemed stifled by neat green lawns.â ” I had begun to regularly commute to the city by train or car from Long Island in my early teens. My lifelong fascination was becoming a full-blown love affair. New York City was alive in a way the suburbs couldnât touch: teeming with the creative expression and diversity that seemed stifled by neat green lawns and nice families. In 1975, I was devouring theatre on and off Broadway, the sprouting art scene in Soho, the cafes and jazz clubs of Greenwich Village and the concerts at Carnegie Hall, the Beacon Theatre and Lincoln Center and in Central Park. Gerald Ford didnât frighten me. I was already a New Yorker in my mind. Iâve lived here, in three different boroughs, since 1981. Itâs sometimes said, âThis city is for the young and the rich.â Iâve been young in New York, and my life here has been more than rich. Iâve watched the Thanksgiving Day Parade from the Dakota and had gigs waiting tables and driving Rolls Royces. Iâve done carpentry and painting, and had too many sunrises legal proofreading. Iâve taken over restaurants in water-pistol fights with Andy Warhol, Jerry Hall and the artist Keith Haring; walked the avenue with Gregory Peck as he obliged Atticus fans by graciously kissing their babies. âThe leaners are going to reject a NYC that isnât how theyâve decided itâs supposed to remain. The lifters will look to care for and tend to the needs of the present,â writes Matthew Conlon. (Photo: New York, April 2020 by Angela Weiss/AFP via Getty.) You canât put a âbest beforeâ tag on New York. Iâve had after-hours encounters with the legendary jazz bass player Jaco Pastorius and Sassy (Sarah Vaughan) in Harlem. They were the days when creativity, the feeling of possibility and, yes, crime, were high in New York. I was robbed at gunpoint and humbled in service for the homeless: Park Avenue to park bench! But it is an unfinished journey. And yet itâs becoming a trend of late to pronounce New York dead. A recent Twitter TWTR, -0.23% Â retweet by President Trump said: âLeave Democrat cities. Let them rot.â A piece in MarketWatch this month quoted a financial author and âproudâ New Yorker who bemoaned the COVID-related loss of the commercial and residential real-estate frenzy, cultural gatherings and his favorite restaurants. He predicts a permanent flight from Gotham: âItâs finished.â He said it wonât recover this time. âThis is different!â he said. Of course, itâs different. Itâs always different. No one had ever incinerated buildings with jetliners until 19 years ago. As I recall, all of these gloomy inevitabilities were looming post-9/11, as a city galvanized and girded, uniting against terror and dread. It was a wonder to behold. And this time is different from 9/11. Something that returns as different â even vastly different â is not dead. Recovery and redemption are not âdeadâ or âfinished.â There are things lost forever about the scrappy New York of the â70s that I miss and there are things about the hyper-monetized New York of 2019 that I would gladly part with. But change isnât death. âSomething that returns as different â even vastly different â is not dead,â Matthew Conlon writes. âRecovery and redemption are not dead or finished.â (Photo: New York Daily News cover on Oct. 29, 1975.) Dispatches from a Pandemic: New York is reminiscent of the Wild West ghost town of my youth â our cityâs future depends on our collective fortitude Doubtless, New York City is down and reeling: More than 32,000 souls perished in the dark months when New York state was the epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic. The loss and fear were traumatizing. There has been significant flight of businesses and residents, and a gutting of indoor gatherings in theaters, restaurants and the like. I, for one, will not forsake my city. She stole my heart when I was 5. I was working out of town in mid-March when my work was suspended. I have remained away in a bubble since quarantine to be available to my fragile, elderly parents on Long Island, and keep them in their home. My wife and I return to our apartment periodically and continue to pay rent and overhead on our city businesses. “ âThe great metropolises â Rome, Paris, London, Berlin â have all been wracked by plagues and war and upheaval.â ” Weâre not bailing. New York is where we trained for and entered our professions. Itâs where we met and fell in love and married. But more than that, New York is where we made a compact to commune with the entirety of humanity, not just the people like us. We live in a time fueled by grievance and entitlement. Sure, the narcissists of the world have always come to New York. But New York has also always been the destination for dreams and possibility. The bemoaning of a lost New York City of sensory indulgence ignores the wealth of history of the city I revere: the city of inclusion, of the great societal advances that followed the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire and the Great Depression. New York and New Yorkers donât kick her when sheâs down. We roll up our sleeves and help. The loss of residents and businesses, of restaurants, bars and theaters, is terrible. The road back will be arduous, and no one can know what lies ahead. Itâs the same the world over. As someone once said, âWeâre in the hallway,â unsure of where it leads. Nobody likes the hallway. Not âknowingâ sucks. âThe city I revere: the city of inclusion, of the great societal advances that followed the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire and the Great Depression.â (Photo: New York, August 1979 by Frances M. Ginter/Getty.) To say New York is finished, however, gravely underestimates the human heart and spirit that have always infused her. The extraordinary capacity of New Yorkers was revealed in both the nightly celebration of health-care and essential workers, and in the humility and discipline that have made the city and state the model for how to quash and reopen in the midst of a novel coronavirus. Whatâs more, not everyone can leave. My Brooklyn-born dad always spoke to me of âlifters and leaners.â The âleanersâ are going to reject a New York that isnât how theyâve decided itâs supposed to remain. The âliftersâ will look to care for and tend to the needs of the present. In many ways, the rampant income inequality and gentrification of the past 20 years were bound for a correction of some kind. They werenât sustainable. New York will become something itâs never been before. Kinder and gentler? Weâll see. But finished? Pshaw! Tough times lay ahead. New York is not going to be âfinishedâ by a pandemic, though. The great metropolises â Rome, Paris, London, Berlin â have all been wracked by plagues and war and upheaval. And the throngs return, as they will to New York, a great metropolis. Death knell be damned. Go ahead â kvetch. Leave! Get out of the way; thereâs good work to be done. Matthew Conlon is an actor based in New York City.
